questions.text: A dairy farmer presented to the dermatology OPD with an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm. Which of the following media will be used as selective  medium for the growth of responsible organism?
questions.solution:
Based on the profession of the person and clinical description of the lesion-its most likely cutaneous anthrax (the most common form of Anthrax) and a selective medium used for it is PLET (polymyxin-lysozyme-EDTA-thallous acetate) medium.

About other options:

  • Buffered charcoal yeast extract is used for Legionella.
  • Cetrimide agar is a selective medium for Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Mannitol, Egg Yolk, Phenol red, Polymyxin Agar (MYPA) medium is a selective medium for Bacillus cereus.

questions.text: All of the following are defence against professional negligence except
questions.solution:
Vicarious liability is not a defence against professional negligence.

Vicarious liability(liability for act of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Defences Against Negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - may be therapeutic, diagnostic and experimental
  • Error of judgement
  • Contributory negligence - absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant

Option B :

Res judicata (S.300, Cr.P.C.) -

  • If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option A :

Limitation (Res indicata) -

  • A suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed.

Option C :

  • Therapeutic misadventure may serve as a defense against negligence. It basically refers to an adverse outcome that could not have been anticipated despite reasonable care. Say a rare side effect of a drug or blood loss due to an anomalous artery despite exercising caution.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl has been deaf since birth.Laboratory reports confirmed hypothyroidism and mutated SLC26A4 gene which is suggestive of Pendred syndrome. Which of the following steps in the thyroid hormone biosynthesis is expected to be primarily defective in her?

choices.text: Internalisation of colloid into the follicular cells
Secretion of the thyroglobulin into the colloid
Iodide trapping and transport into the follicular cells
Iodide transport across the apical membrane in to the colloid

questions.solution:
In Pendred syndrome the transport of iodide across the apical membrane into the colloid is affected in this case.

Pendrin (coded by SLC26A4) is one of the members of the larger family of SLC26 anion exchangers. In the thyroid gland, it is located in the apical membrane of the follicular cell and transports iodide into the colloid in exchange for the chloride ion.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone:

  1. Thyroglobulin synthesis by thyroid follicular cells.
  2. Iodide trapping: Na+-I- symporter (NIS) actively transports I- into the follicular cells. This is inhibited by thiocyanate and perchlorate anions and is stimulated by TSH.
  3. Iodide is transported into the lumen of the follicle by I--Cl- transporter called pendrin.
  4. Oxidation of I- to I2 catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase (TPO).
  5. Organification/Iodination of tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin: Binding of I2  to tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin to form MIT (monoiodotyrosine) and DIT (diiodotyrosine). Catalyzed by TPO.
  6. Coupling reaction mediated by TPO: MIT + DIT → T3, DIT + DIT → T4.
  7. Storage and release: T3 and T4 are stored bound to thyroglobulin. When stimulated, they are cleaved from thyroglobulin and released into the circulation.

questions.text: On observing the presence of Fleischer vortex(whorl keratopathy) during the ocular examination of a patient, you would expect to find a history of intake of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy/ Fleisher vortex/ whorl keratopathy.

Long-term treatment with chloroquine may sometimes cause whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata.

Other causes of corneal verticillata: 

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines
  • Atovaquone

Other side effects of Chloroquine are:

  • Gastrointestinal (common): Abdominal cramps, anorexia, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting
  • Cardiovascular: Atrioventricular block, bundle branch block, cardiac arrhythmia, cardiac failure, cardiomyopathy, ECG changes, hypotension, torsades de pointes, ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia
  • Dermatologic: Alopecia, bleaching of hair, blue-grey skin pigmentation, erythema multiforme, exacerbation of psoriasis, urticaria, etc
  • Endocrine & metabolic: Exacerbation of porphyria, severe hypoglycemia
  • Hematologic & oncologic: Agranulocytosis (reversible), aplastic anemia, hemolytic anemia (in G6PD-deficient patients), neutropenia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic: Hepatitis, increased liver enzymes
  • Nervous system: Agitation, anxiety, confusion, decreased deep tendon reflex, delirium, depression, extrapyramidal reaction (dystonia, dyskinesia, protrusion of the tongue, torticollis) etc
  • Neuromuscular & skeletal: Asthenia, myopathy, neuromuscular disease, proximal myopathy
  • Ophthalmic: Accommodation disturbances, blurred vision, corneal opacity (reversible), macular degeneration (may be irreversible), maculopathy (may be irreversible), night blindness, retinal pigment changes (bull’s eye appearance), retinopathy (including irreversible changes in long-term or high-dose therapy), transient scotomata, visual field defect (paracentral scotomas)
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines, as shown in the image below, is called corneal verticillata.

Image below shows increased fluorescence in the macular area and round-shaped blocked fluorescence in the central fovea. It is likely due chloroquine toxicity.

Other options:

  • Commonly seen side effects with leflunomide are headache, alopecia, skin rash, diarrhea and nausea.

  • Commonly seen side effects with primaquine are gastrointestinal, cardiac arrhythmia, dizziness, pruritus, skin rash, anemia, hemolytic anemia (in patients with G6PD deficiency), leukopenia and methemoglobinemia (in NADH-methemoglobin reductase-deficient individuals)

  • Commonly seen side effects with apraclonidine are gastrointestinal, xerostomia, eye discomfort, eye pruritus and ocular hyperemia.

questions.text: Identify the subtype of Hodgkin’s lymphoma based on the cell marked as A in the image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows popcorn cell which is characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

Popcorn cell is lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of RS cells that has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn.

L&H variants usually are found within large nodules containing mainly small B cells along with variable numbers of macrophages. The immunophenotype is CD20+ve, CD15−ve and C30−ve 

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence. But, lymphocyte depleted has the strongest association with HIV.

questions.text: Regarding the disposal of refuse, which of the following is a controlled tipping method?
questions.solution:
Ramp method is a type of controlled tipping method. 

Controlled tipping or sanitary landfill is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. The material is placed in a trench or other prepared area, adequately compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the working day. There are three methods under controlled tipping:

  1. The trench method
  2. The ramp method
  3. The area method

Other methods of refuse disposal:

  • Dumping: Refuse is dumped into low lying areas by throwing it in open space.
  • Incineration: It is the method of choice of disposal by burning when suitable land is not available.
  • Composting:
    • This is a method of combined disposal of refuse and sludge.
    • Compost has manorial value for soil.
    • It includes 2 methods:
      • Bangalore method - Anaerobic composting
      • Indore method - Aerobic mechanical composting
  • Manure pits: Commonly used in rural areas in India.
  • Burial: Suitable for small camps.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for:
questions.solution:
The test shown in the above image is Titmus stereotest, which is done to test for stereopsis (perception of depth).

  • The pictures consist of a housefly for children and circular patterns for adults.
  • The picture is held in front of the eyes of the patient at a distance of about 16 inches and the patient is asked to wear polarized glasses. 
  • If the patient's perception of the depth is normal, the housefly appears to rise above the plane, like a 3D image. If the patient is asked to pinch the wings of the housefly, he/she will try to pinch in the air, above the plane of the image. This is normal.
  • If the patient's perception of depth in either eye is defective, then the image appears just like normal 2D image.

questions.text: A patient being treated with Phenelzine came to the emergency department with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis following dinner at the restaurant and his  BP is 190/120.  The patient is diagnosed with a cheese reaction. Consumption of any of the following foods could have caused cheese reaction except:
questions.solution:
Cheese reaction is seen on consumption on tyramine rich foods such as cheese, red wine, aged meat, and fish, etc. Apples do not cause a cheese reaction.

Cheese reaction occurs in patients being treated with MAO inhibitors who consume tyramine rich foods. Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter the circulation. A hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of a powerful pressor effect of tyramine. 

The hypertensive crisis in cheese rection is treated with Phentolamine.

questions.text: An anesthesia resident asks you to load the following neuromuscular blocker, as you were posted as an intern in the anesthesia department. You would expect to see the return of the first twitch of a train of four after ___________ from administering a normal dose of this agent
questions.solution:
Vecuronium is an intermediate-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker. So, one can expect to see the return of first twitch of a train of four (signifying recovery) after 20-50 minutes from administering this agent

Note: Vecuronium is a pancuronium minus a quaternary methyl group. This minor structural change beneficially alters side effects without affecting its potency.

choices.text: Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia during extension
Medial rotation of the femur on tibia during flexion
Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia during flexion
Medial rotation of the femur on tibia during extension

questions.solution:
Locking of knee is medial rotation of femur on tibia during the later stages of extension.

  • Locking of the knee joint: When standing, the knee joint is locked into position to reduce the amount of muscle work needed to maintain the standing position. The muscle responsible for locking is vastus medialis.
  • Unlocking of the knee joint: It is the lateral rotation of femur on tibia during the beginning of flexion. This is brought by the action of popliteus muscle.

questions.text: What is the most likely etiology for the erythematous streak-like  lesions on the trunk as shown in the image below?

choices.text: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO

questions.solution:
The type of erythema seen in the image is flagellate erythema, seen as a side effect of Bleomycin chemotherapy. 

Flagellate erythema is characterized by multiple red, macular streaks of erythema on the trunk and limbs. The streaks are aligned in a criss‐cross pattern, giving a whip-like or flagellate appearance. They may be sore or pruritic. 

Flagellate erythema is seen in:

  • A side effect of Bleomycin chemotherapy
  • Toxic effect after consumption of shitake mushrooms
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Adult-onset Still’s disease
  • Docetaxel therapy

It is self-limiting and usually resolves within a few days to weeks. Topical steroids and oral antihistamines can be given to relieve the associated pruritis.

Other options:

Option A: Therapy with doxorubicin causes generalized hypopigmentation.

Option C: Burrowing of Hookworm larvae in the skin causes a creeping eruption characterized by linear twisting and winding lesions mainly on the feet and hands. It is shown in the image below.

 

Option D: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO is responsible for Incontinentia pigmenti. It follows 4 stages of cutaneous lesions- erythematous vesicular rash, verrucous lesions, hyperpigmented whorls, and atrophic streaks respectively. Lesions are seen along the lines of Blaschko.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement with respect to the X-ray shown below.

choices.text: The structure marked number 2 is the right ventricular border
The structure marked 1 is the trachea
The structure marked 3 is the left ventricular border
The structure marked 4 is the aortic arch

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option A because the structure marked as 2 is the right atrial border (not the right ventricular border). The given image is posteroanterior (PA) view of a normal chest x-ray. Structures marked in the X-Ray are as follows:

  1. Trachea
  2. Right atrial border
  3. Left ventricular border
  4. Aortic arch

Chest x-rays can be described as posteroanterior (PA) or anteroposterior (AP) views. This indicates the direction in which the x-ray beam traverses from the patient to the detector.

PA view means that the x-ray beam enters from the posterior aspect of the patient and exits anteriorly to reach the film.

AP view means that the x-ray beam enters the patient from the anterior aspect and exits from the posterior aspect, reaching the film.

A left lateral decubitus view is one taken with the patient’s left side down.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presented with cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth. The tongue is slightly pushed to the right side. He also complains of pain off and on. He is likely to be suffering from _______
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests ranula.

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that takes on the appearance of a ‘frog’s belly’. Ranula is derived from ‘Rana’, the Latin for frog.

A ranula can resolve spontaneously, but many also require active treatment. The traditional and effective way is to remove the sublingual gland, but it is not an easy operation and the morbidity can be significant.

Other options:

  • Ectopic thyroid: It is a cystic condition. Usually painless. Presents in the midline and will be at the base of the tongue and not on the floor of the mouth.
  • Cystic hygroma: It’s a disease of neonates and early childhood, hence it can be excluded.
  • Vincent’s angina: It is a bilateral condition with a picture of cellulitis. Cysts are not present.

questions.text: A ligament is marked in red in the given image below. According to the Denis three-column concept of spinal stability, the given ligament comes under which column?
questions.solution:
The given ligament marked in red is the posterior longitudinal ligament. It is a component of the middle column.

Denis three-column concept of spinal stability: This was used to describe the classification of spinal injuries.

    • Anterior column:
    • Anterior half of the vertebral body
    • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Anterior longitudinal ligament
  • Middle column:
    • Posterior half of the vertebral body
    • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Posterior longitudinal ligament
  • Posterior column
    • Pedicles
    • Facet joints
    • Posterior bony arch
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Supraspinous ligament

The fractures involving the middle column and at least one other column are regarded as unstable injuries i.e. there is a significant risk of displacement of the vertebral components, leading to damage of the neural tissues.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman who was being treated for a rheumatological disease was recently diagnosed with ovarian and  breast cancer. The image of the characteristic rash is given below. Which of the following autoimmune diseases is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
The following image shows Gottron's papules on hand. This patient is most likely suffering from dermatomyositis which is associated with underlying malignancy and is often considered as a paraneoplastic manifestation. 

The tumors that are commonly associated with DM are ovarian cancer, breast cancer, melanoma, colon cancer, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. The most common malignancy associated with dermatomyositis is ovarian cancer. Most patients with cancer-associated dermatomyositis have antibodies to Nuclear Matrix Protein NXP-2 or Transcription Intermediary factor 1γ (TIF1γ).

The other features which point to a diagnosis of dermatomyositis are

  • Age group 50-60 yrs
  • Proximal myopathy which is manifested as difficulty in climbing stairs, getting up from chairs, lifting hands, etc.
  • Association with internal malignancy

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Facial rash
  • Eyelid erythema and edema
  • Nail fold changes
  • Gottron’s papules
  • Shawl sign which is macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

The given image shows characteristic upper eyelid lilac erythema/heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

V-shaped rash in dermatomyositis.
